At the most recent CMS Conference of the Parties in 2020, it was agreed a species Action Plan would be developed for the European Eel.

Across Europe, programmes for “trap and transport” (downriver transport), and “assisted migration” (upriver transport), are in place to provide eels with access to habitat that has been lost through the construction of migratory barriers. When applied to migrating silver eels, it can have a significant and immediate effect on local escapement. It is hoped that translocation can mitigate against the loss of habitat and positively contribute to enhanced escapement, and by association, future recruitment (e.g. for barriers: van der Meer 2012, McCarthy et al. 2014, Béguer-Pon et al. 2018). There is a necessity in the future, however, to reduce the level of direct human intervention by eliminating the barriers to navigation, or at least, providing more effective passage for eels.

Continuous monitoring of eel escapement on a national or international scale is currently very rare and so in addition to localised monitoring, modelling has been explored for providing estimates of escapement in eel subpopulations. A number of assessment models have been developed; Demographic model of the Camargue (DemCam) (Bevacqua and De Leo 2006), Eel Density Analysis (EDA) (EDA 2.2: Briand et al. 2015, EDA 2.2.1: Briand et al. 2018), German Eel Model (GEM) (GEM II: Oeberst and Fladung 2012, GEM III: Oeberst and Fladung 2014), and, Scenario-based Model of Eel Production II (SMEP II) (SMEP: developed by El-Hosaini, Bark, Knights, Williams and Kirkwood; Aprahamian et al. 2007). Using time series eel data sets from a variety of locations across Europe, earlier iterations of these models were reviewed by Walker et al. (2011). The conclusions of this report suggest that all four models were capable of predicting escapement to a degree of accuracy (Walker et al. 2011).

In 2019,  ICES stated that: “The status of European eel remains critical”, and that “all anthropogenic impacts (e.g. caused by recreational and commercial fishing on all stages, hydropower, pumping stations, and pollution) that decrease production and escapement of silver eels should be reduced to,  or kept as close as possible to,  zero in 2020” (ICES 2019b). In 2019, provisional recruitment estimates remain low across the geographical range. Although, recruitment during the period of 2011–2019 has shown an increasing trend, statistically significant from zero. This highlights the necessity for continued, effective conservation across the range for A. anguilla.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km² combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). Despite the fact that the population trend appears to be decreasing, the decline is not believed to be sufficiently rapid to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is extremely large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: This species breeds in the interior and edge of a variety of deciduous and mixed forest communities, preferring those with a moderate shrub/subcanopy layer and fairly open forest floor, shade, moist soil and decaying leaf litter (del Hoyo et al. 2005). On passage, the species frequents secondary growth and forest edge. In its non-breeding range, it occupies the interior understorey of humid to semi-humid broad-leaved evergreen and semi-deciduous forest and mixed palm forest, also occurring in secondary growth, low-stature forest, thickets and plantations. It feeds mainly on soil-dwelling invertebrates, and takes fruit from late summer to early spring (Jirinec et al. 2016, Evans et al. 2020). It breeds from early May to late August, with pairs typically raising two broods. It is predominantly monogamous, with rare instances of polygyny. Pair bonds usually last for a single season. It is a long-distance nocturnal migrant, leaving its breeding areas in mid-August to mid-September and crossing the Gulf of Mexico on a broad front from Texas to Florida, and making landfall from Veracruz, Mexico to Costa Rica (del Hoyo et al. 2005, Stanley et al. 2015). Individuals leave the non-breeding region during April (Stanley et al. 2012) and most birds (>70%) travel northwards through the central U.S. Gulf Coast (Stanley et al. 2015).
threats: The species is threatened by the loss and fragmentation of its forest habitat both within the breeding and non-breeding ranges (Taylor and Stutchbury 2016, Evans et al. 2020). In fragmented habitats, breeding pairs suffer from lower reproductive success and higher prevalence of cowbird parasitism (Evans et al. 2020). Demographic models suggest that population declines are primarily driven by loss and fragmentation of non-breeding habitat in Central America (Taylor and Stutchbury 2016). Further threats include contamination by acid rain, disturbance at nest sites, pollution and window collisions (Evans et al. 2020).
population: The population is estimated to number 12,000,000 mature individuals (Partners in Flight 2019). It is described as common.
range: Hylocichla mustelina is a widespread breeding visitor to the eastern U.S.A. and south-eastern Canada, wintering in Central America from southern Mexico to Panama.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
This species has been the subject of targeted research and its population trends are captured through established survey programmes.

Conservation Actions Proposed
Continue to monitor population trends through established citizen science programmes. Investigate the possible causes of the decline. Carry out habitat restoration for the species. Increase the area of suitable habitat that receives formal and effective protection in both its breeding and non-breeding ranges; use modelling to aid in strategic conservation planning and predict possible future effects of certain activities (e.g. Bonnot et al. 2011, 2013, Beaudry et al. 2013).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence and area of occupancy both well below 10 km<sup>2</sup>, within which it is threatened by habitat disturbance mainly due to intense tourism and likely from pollution from the Port of Imbituba, which surrounds the only known location, causing ongoing decline in habitat quality and extent.
habitat: The species occurs in the Atlantic Forest and is restricted to a small and isolated granite outcrop, the hill Morro do Farol (Kunz and Borges-Martins 2013). This has an area of 1,200 x 500 m, at 100 m above sea level, and is surrounded by an extensive sandy plateau occupied by the city of Imbituba. Its vegetation is scrub grassland and humid coastal forest. The biology of this species is unknown.
threats: Although the hill where the species occurs is relatively well-preserved, the large number of tourists visiting the area is degrading its habitat quality through such impacts as trampling and litter. Pollution from the port of Imbituba is also degrading habitat quality.
population: The species is restricted to a single subpopulation, on the mountain Morro do Farol in the state of Santa Catarina. There is insufficient information on population abundance and trends.
range: This lizard is endemic to southern Brazil. It has a single record in the beach Praia da Vila, in the hill Morro do Farol, municipality of Imbituba, state of de Santa Catarina (Kunz and Borges-Martins 2013). Although the state and the area of the hill have been thoroughly surveyed, the species has not been found anywhere else. Its area of occupancy was estimated to be 4 km<sup>2</sup>, but within this area the estimated area of suitable habitat is 0.6 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Its range is encompassed by the Plano de Ação Nacional para a Conservação dos Anfíbios e Répteis Ameaçados da Região Sul do Brasil (Brazil 2012). It is not known from protected areas. Further surveys and studies on its biology and ecology are needed to clarify the extent of impacts from identified threats, and creation of a protected area to conserve the natural vegetation of the Morro do Farol is recommended.

rationale: This intra-African migratory species is threatened by destruction and degradation of its grassland and wetland habitats on both its breeding grounds and its non-breeding grounds. The destruction of natural habitat has been found to have led to a rapid reduction of its already small population, which is projected to continue in the future unless immediate conservation action is taken across its entire distribution range. The species is therefore classified as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species breeds in montane grassland (Keith et al. 1992, Berruti et al. 1995, Holroyd and Quinn undated), preferring high rainfall, undulating areas such as mist belt grasslands of South Africa (Evans 2000). It favours grassland with interspersed with drainage lines in gullies or valleys, and also frequents wetland systems such as pans and small dams (Anon. 2005b). The species requires such wetlands among grassland patches for foraging (Anon. 2005b). In Swaziland, its breeding sites have been restricted to grasslands above 1,200 m, with most above 1,300 m (Monadjem et al. 2006). Prior to its northwards migration, it may congregate akin to Barn Swallow, Hirundo rustica, giving twittering calls (Meikle 2012). In its non-breeding range it favours open grassland, often with bushes and trees (Keith et al. 1992, Ndang'ang'a 2004, Ndang'ang'a 2007) and marshy areas (Ndang'ang'a 2007). Its nest is usually attached to the roof or side of a hole in the ground (relatively free of vegetation) (Turner and Rose 1989, Keith et al. 1992, Johnson 1996). Nest-sites in South Africa and Swaziland include underground sinkholes or disused aardvark Orycteropus afer burrows (Mattison 2003, Wakelin 2004, Monadjem et al. 2006), as well as artificial and artificially altered holes (Mattison 2003, Monadjem et al. 2006) such as old mining and prospecting shafts (Meikle 2010). Birds use the same nest-site for up to 30 years (Keith et al. 1992, S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000), as long as the cavity remains stable (Wakelin 2004), although it is not known whether these are the same birds returning (J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). The nest consists of a cup of mud, mixed with fine grass and rootlets, and lined with feathers, and is repaired each year (Wakelin 2004). The species has been recorded breeding cooperatively in some parts of its range (facultative cooperative breeder) (Wakelin 2004, S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). However, it is not known whether helpers are related to the breeding pair (Wakelin 2004). Nesting occurs between October and March (Monadjem et al. 2006). A successful pair may produce two broods per breeding season (Wakelin 2004, Monadjem et al. 2006), with three clutches fledged from one nest in KwaZulu-Natal (J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). It lays two or three eggs, normally three; incubation lasts about 15 days and the chicks fledge after about 22 days (Wakelin 2004). The total number of active nests seems to be positively correlated with rainfall prior to breeding, probably through its influence on the abundance of insects, which the species feeds on (Monadjem et al. 2006). Blue swallow often forage in dense fog. They are well adapted to these conditions, having the most water repellent plumage of any terrestrial bird species (Rijke et al. 2000, Kylin et al. 2011).
threats: Grassland in many parts of its range is being lost to afforestation (Keith et al. 1992, Wakelin 2004), intense human settlement, cultivation (especially sugarcane [Evans 2000]), intensive livestock-farming, intense grazing, intensive grass-burning (Nasirwa and Njoroge 1997), invasion by non-native trees and bracken (S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000) and (potentially) small-scale mining (S. W. Evans verbally 1998). Grasslands are burnt annually or sometimes biannually to stimulate new growth for grazing; annual burning and grazing alters the composition of plant species and reduces their cover, accelerating soil erosion, reducing the organic content of soil and thus insect abundance and reducing the productivity and diversity of grasslands (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007, J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). The drainage of wetlands also threatens the species (Anon. 2005b). More than 60% of the South African Grassland Biome Habitat has already been irreversibly transformed (Evans 2000). Only 0.24% of montane grassland in KwaZulu-Natal is protected (Wakelin 2004). At five study sites in KwaZulu-Natal, 55% of the suitable grassland habitat was transformed between 1980 and 2000, and the number of active nests also halved (Wakelin 2004, M. McNamara in litt. 2006). At these sites, in addition to afforestation which doubled in area over the 20 year period and also accounted for half of the total land-use of the study area, grassland was also altered by the encroachment of woody vegetation, as a result of a lack of fuelwood harvesting by displaced communities and changes in fire regimes and timber plantation management (Wakelin 2004, J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). In Mpumalanga, 61% of suitable habitat in the North-eastern Mountain Sourveld has been transformed (M. McNamara in litt. 2006). Nesting attempts by the species in Mpumalanga and Limpopo Provinces (South Africa) were thought to be adversely affected by cold, dry conditions in October and November 2004 (Anon. 2005b), probably as a result of a low abundance of insects. In Swaziland, 42% of potentially suitable grassland above 1,300 m has been transformed or heavily degraded since the 1950s (Monadjem et al. 2006). Suitable breeding habitat in this country has been lost mostly to afforestation for exotic timber plantations, as well as urbanisation to a lesser extent (Monadjem et al. 2006). The Busia Grasslands (Kenya) have lost over 60% of their grassland cover since the mid-1990s (Ndang'ang'a 2007). They are surrounded by intensive agriculture, mainly maize and sugarcane (Ndang'ang'a 2004, Ndang'ang'a 2007), and are grazed by livestock (Ndang'ang'a 2007). The grasslands are severely and immediately threatened by fragmentation, agriculture and overgrazing (Ndang'ang'a 2004) from the large, rapidly increasing human population (Ndang'ang'a 2007) in adjacent settlements, some of which are highly populated (Ndang'ang'a 2004). Local people in Busia commonly trap swallows for food, and this may include H. atrocaerulea (Ndang'ang'a 2007, P. K. Ndang'ang'a in litt. 2007). The loss of grasslands outside the Ruma National Park (Kenya) is severe, with almost every available area cultivated, heavily grazed or settled (Ndang'ang'a 2007). The species's nest-site fidelity (Wakelin 2004) may increase its susceptibility to the affects of habitat transformation. Breeding birds are known to abandon their nests in reaction to human disturbance from excessive tourism (Mattison 2003) and land-owners (Wakelin 2004). At the Blue Swallow Natural Heritage Site (BSNHS), South Africa, nesting success has been reported to decline during years with increased fog (Evans and Bouwman 2000). Blue Swallows are well-adapted to flying in dense fog and have the most water repellent plumage of any terrestrial bird species (Rijke et al. 2000). Kylin et al. (2011) hypothesise that elevated concentrations of sulphonates in the fog, caused by a combination of increased air pollution from the Johannesburg area and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) released from exotic trees, may have increased the wettability of the blue swallow plumage and lowered nesting success.
population: The total population has declined by an estimated 36–56% since the 1850s, and has been estimated at 1,006 pairs or 2,012 individuals (Evans and Bouwman 2010), and between 1,169 and 1,338 pairs (Evans et al. 2016). Estimated numbers of breeding pairs should be treated with caution, as when nests are surveyed they are assumed to indicate one breeding pair each, which may not be the case in this facultative cooperative breeder, and it has been observed that some nests are not used after construction (J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). It is conservatively placed in the band 1,000-2,499 mature individuals given the uncertainty over estimated numbers, and the maximum number of pairs is only just above this range. This equates to 1,500-3,749 individuals in total, rounded here to 1,500-4,000 individuals.
range: Hirundo atrocaerulea is an intra-African migrant that breeds in South Africa, west Swaziland, Zimbabwe, Malawi (F. Dowsett-Lemaire and R. J. Dowsett in litt. 1999, 2000, Holroyd and Quinn undated), north-east Zambia, south-western Tanzania (N. Baker in litt. 1999, D. Moyer in litt. 1999), west Mozambique, and south-east Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) (Keith et al. 1992). It is a non-breeding visitor to north-east DRC, south Uganda (M. Carswell in litt. 1999) and west Kenya (Keith et al. 1992). 74% of the total breeding population occurs in Zimbabwe, Malawi and southern Tanzania. Uganda and Kenya host an estimated 73% of the non-breeding population (Evans and Bouwman 2010). It is uncommon to rare in Zambia and Zimbabwe and close to extinction in Swaziland and South Africa (Evans and Barnes 2000) where its population is estimated at around 100 pairs (Monadjem et al. 2006), though this could be as low as 40 pairs (McKechnie and Little 2012). The species range in South Africa and Swaziland is thought to have contracted by 74% (Evans and Bouwman 2010). It is reported that no active nests were located in Swaziland in 2006 (J. Wakelin in litt. 2007). There were thought to be 84 pairs in South Africa in 2005 (Anon. 2005b, M. McNamara in litt. 2006). The species was not recorded in Limpopo Province during national surveys in 2003 (Mattison 2004, Anon. 2005a) and 2004 (Anon. 2005a, Anon. 2005b), and it is not thought to have nested in the province during those seasons (Anon. 2005b). The total population has declined by an estimated 36–56% since the 1850s, and is now estimated at 1,006 pairs or 2,012 individuals (Evans and Bouwman 2010), or between 1,169 and 1,338 pairs (Evans et al. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
CMS Appendix I and II. In 1986, an international working group was established for the conservation and recovery of the species throughout its range (Anon. 2005b). The group has helped to prevent afforestation of the species's grasslands and wetlands in five key areas, successfully lobbied for grasslands in eight areas to be rehabilitated, and succeeded in blocking prospecting and mining in two key areas in South Africa (M. McNamara per Anon. 2005b). A workshop was held in South Africa in June 2002, followed by the publication of an international action plan (Evans et al. 2002). A South African working group has been formed to coordinate and encourage conservation of the species (Evans 2000, Holroyd and Quinn undated). In Malawi, Nyika National Park and the Mulanje area are considered secure from agricultural encroachment in the long term, owing to the cold climate and poor soils (F. Dowsett-Lemaire in litt. 1997). In Zimbabwe, c.200 pairs breed within Nyanga National Park (S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000), and less than 50 pairs breed in Chimanimani National Park (S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000). The Ruma National Park is a stronghold for the species in Kenya (Ndang'ang'a 2007). The majority of the few known pairs in Swaziland breed in Malolotja Nature Reserve (Parker 1994, Monadjem et al. 2006), with two pairs in recent years on Sibebe Mountain, which has been the focus of a community-based conservation project (Monadjem et al. 2006). In Mpumalanga and KwaZulu-Natal, artificial nest cavities have been dug (Wakelin 2004, Anon. 2005b, S. W. Evans in litt. 2007) to encourage the species into previously unoccupied areas where there are no natural nest sites (Anon. 2005b), and some remain in use (Wakelin 2004). However, artificial nests are less warm than natural nests, and the possible impacts of this for breeding in this species are, as of yet, still uncertain (Wakelin et al. 2013). Of the 44 artificial nest sites created in KwaZulu-Natal, 18 have been used once or more, but 26 remain unused (Anon. 2005b). Research is underway in South Africa to investigate the minimum size of grassland required by breeding pairs through the use of radio-tracking and wing-marking studies (Wakelin 2004). The species's breeding success in South Africa is monitored anuually (Mattison 2003, S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). In South Africa, a national count (Mattison 2004, Arnott 2004, Anon. 2005a) and breeding survey in KwaZulu-Natal (Mattison 2003, Arnott 2004) and Mpumalanga (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007) are carried out annually in October-November. Environmental education programmes are ongoing in the regions of South Africa where the species breeds (M. McNamara in litt. 2006).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Identify key wintering sites and conserve them (L. Bennun in litt. 1999). Survey and monitor breeding population size and trend at less well-studied sites (M. Dyer in litt. 1999, S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000). Control and remove non-native plants at breeding sites (S. L. Childes in litt. 1999, 2000). Assess effects of grassland fires on spread of non-native plants. Prevent further loss of grassland habitat in Kenya (Ndang'ang'a 2004). Survey the species's entire range in Swaziland to obtain data on its breeding population (Monadjem et al. 2006). In Swaziland, increase the area of protected grassland above 1,300 m (Monadjem et al. 2006). Consider the burning of grassland patches to prevent shrub and tree encroachment and encourage swarms of insects for the species to feed on (Ndang'ang'a 2007). Initiate a conservation strategy for the Busia Grasslands that can incorporate development (Ndang'ang'a 2007). Raise public awareness of the species's plight and importance of its habitat (M. McNamara in litt. 2006). Prevent any further significant loss of suitable habitat in South Africa (M. McNamara in litt. 2006). Reduce disturbance by tourists and land-owners. Study habitat use in its wintering range (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Determine the characteristics of drainage lines used or foraging (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Identify migration routes used between breeding and wintering grounds (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Study breeding biology in greater detail, including the effects of differences in conditions within natural and artificial nest holes (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Carry out surveys to obtain a population estimate for southern Tanzania (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Study the species's demography and longevity (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007). Study the genetics and taxonomy of the species (S. W. Evans in litt. 2007).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,623 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least four but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This terrestrial species is associated with wet leaf-litter, rocks and other ground cover, and occurs close to streams in tropical wet montane forest. This species is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its breeding strategy has not been recorded, but reproduction presumably takes place in water, probably in streams, by larval development.
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a potential threat. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species, especially within the Peak Wilderness Reserve. This could potentially be a result of climate change or pollution, however the exact cause is unknown. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat.
range: This species was previously only known from the Kitulgala Forest Reserve, Messana Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve [at low elevations] and Sinharaja World Heritage Site in southwestern Sri Lanka. It has now also been recorded from Erathna in Sripada and Udamaliboda (D. Gabadage pers. comm. February 2020). It occurs at elevations ranging between 150-1,070 m asl. This species is thought to be restricted to its known range and is therefore unlikely to occur much more widely than what is currently mapped (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this updated distribution is 3,623 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent at least four but no more than five threat-defined locations due to the changing intensity of encroaching agriculture and development across its range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas, including the Kitulgala Forest Reserve, Messana Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve and the Sinharaja World Heritage Site.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agricultural work in the area.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 342 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in lentic habitats, in upper montane grassland, and wet evergreen forest. Adults are generally found close to pool and grassland edges, while larvae are found in both permanent and seasonal pools. At night, vocalizing individuals have been observed at the edges of shallow pools (< 0.3 m in depth) in an open grassland. The grass was emergent in most areas of the pools, which had a muddy substrate but contained clear water (Garg et al. 2018). This species is thought to tolerant a degree of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
The major threat to this species is habitat loss caused by conversion to intensive agricultural use (e.g. vegetables), including the resulting pollution from pesticide use. Other threats include soil erosion and land filling within its range. Additionally, various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). 

Climate change also presents a threat, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is rare (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the central hills of Sri Lanka at elevations between 1,800-2,200 m asl, and it is thought to be restricted to its currently mapped range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this range is 342 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from Horton Plains National Park, Pattipola Forest Reserve, Agra-Bopath Forest Reserve, and Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of drought, fire, and habitat loss through conversion to intensive agricultural use.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,297 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is generally restricted to montane tropical moist forest habitats. Adults can be found in leaf-litter (and are at least partially fossorial), under stones and other ground cover, beneath bark, on the trunks of trees, and in the canopy. Breeding is thought to take place by larval development, like other members of its genus. Some observations suggest that this species is a facultative tree-hole breeder because calling males and tadpoles have also been found in shallow pools adjacent to forest edges, and in small streams (Wijayathilaka et al. 2018). This species is not likely to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
The principal cause of decline appears to be habitat loss caused by the conversion of forests to cultivated land (tea plantations), logging with subsequent replanting of plantation forests (in Pattipola) and droughts and fire (especially in Horton Plains National Park). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, the high volume of tourists entering the areas poses a threat to this species as many bathe in the stream waters, thereby introducing various pollutants and disturbing the aquatic environments. Additionally, throughout the central hills region various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species across its range, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in the area near Peak Wilderness and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al.2013).
population: This species is rare (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the central hills of Sri Lanka where it has been recorded at elevations between 1,400-2,135 m asl. Niche modeling in 2018 indicated that this species has a predicted distribution of 982 km2, entirely within the central hills at elevations above 1,300 m asl in Nuwara-Eliya, Horton Plains National Park and Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Wijayathilaka et al. 2018). This species is likely restricted to its known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this distribution is 1,297 km2, which is thought to represent at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In addition to the previously reported Horton Plains National Park and Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve, this species has also been recorded from Agra-Bopats Forest Reserve and Pattipola Forest Reserve, and Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss through the conversion of forests to cultivated land and plantation forests, as well as droughts, fire and die-back of mature trees.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,267 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is associated with wetland habitats (including riparian vegetation) within montane tropical moist forest, and is not present in modified habitats. Adults are both aquatic and terrestrial, and may be found under grass tussocks. Larvae are present in shallow, vegetated, slow-flowing waters and marshes. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
This species is threatened by habitat loss caused by encroaching agriculture (specifically tea plantations), pollution from agro-chemicals, and from the desiccation of wetlands and forest fires in Horton Plains. Throughout the Central Hills various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. Additionally, tourism poses a threat as visitors frequently leave behind garbage and exploit the forest, often in the form of small-scale wood extraction (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). 

Climate change also presents a threat, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in Peak Wilderness and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane (‘cloud’) forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). 

Predation by trout was previously listed as a threat, however it has been present in the area for over 100 years and is no longer thought to pose a threat as the species has adapted (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is restricted to the central hills of Sri Lanka, including the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, and is unlikely to occur more widely. It occurs at elevations between 1,200 - 2,135 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,267 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is known from five or fewer threat-defined locations due to differing intensities of habitat loss due to encroaching agriculture.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Horton Plains National Park, Agra-Bopats Forest Reserve, Pattipola Forest Reserve, and the Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve. It has also been recorded from Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve and Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (S. Karunarathna, D. Gabadage, and M. Botejue pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss, pollution, desiccation of wetlands, forest fires, tourism, and climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,628 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 4-5 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is found mostly on shrubs (usually less than 0.3-2 m above ground) in montane tropical forest, forest edge (bordering tea plantations) and in anthropogenic habitats such as home gardens and roadsides (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It is active during both day and night, and at night adult males perch on branches and leaves and vocalize (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It breeds by direct development, and is not dependent upon water. The  female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited. This species is fairly tolerant to habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
This species is thought to be threatened by encroaching intensive small-scale crop agriculture and the resulting pesticide use within its range. It is also threatened by the construction of power lines (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is common in suitable habitat. A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously thought to be endemic to the Horton Plains and Pattipola, in the Central Hill Country of Sri Lanka. It is now also known from the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (Peabotuwage et al. 2012), Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve (Ukuwela unpub. data February 2020), Loolcondera (also known as Loolkandura), and Rilhena Estate in Sabaragamuwa Province (S. Goonatilake unpub. data February 2020). It is not thought to be found more widely than currently mapped. Within this expanded distribution, the species occurs at elevations between 1,300-2,135 m asl (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,628 km2, and it is thought to occur in 4-5 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in Horton Plains National Park, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Great Western Forest Reserve, Piduruthalagala, and Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of expanding small-scale agriculture and the resulting pollution, as well as the construction of power lines within its range.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,597 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in open areas within montane forest, as well as in slightly disturbed habitats such as roadsides adjacent to forest. It is somewhat tolerant to habitat disturbance, however it requires a degree of forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It is a cryptic species; calling adult males are most often seen at night perched high on shrubs, 1.5-3 m above the ground (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding is by direct development, and is not dependent upon water. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited.
threats:
The major threat to this species is the degradation and loss of its habitat. This species is threatened by pollution from pesticides and chemical fertilizers used in the surrounding tea plantations within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka with millions of visitors; especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season during which a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously thought to be rare, however due to increased survey effort it is now known to be seasonally common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the Central Hills region of Sri Lanka, and is found at elevations between 10-1,830 m asl. There are records from Moray, Agra Bopath and Dayagama (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005), as well as from Aulton Watta, Brownslow, Maskeliya, Maussakele, Sri Palabaddala, Seethagangula, Waggama, and Labukele (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). All records from the Corbett's Gap area within the Knuckles Mountain Range of central Sri Lanka and those from nearby Bambarella Peak that were previously allocated to Pseudophilautus hoffmanni have now been assigned to this species (Ellepola et al. 2021). These areas, the Knuckles Mountain Range and all other known localities, make up two distinct subpopulations of this species. This species is likely to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,597 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary and Knuckles Mountain Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture, tourism, and pollution.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 507 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This terrestrial species is forest-dependent, only found in closed-canopy habitats within both disturbed and undisturbed forests, and has also been observed in shaded home gardens adjacent to forests (M. Wickramasinghe and M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Adults are strictly nocturnal; males have been observed perching on branches of low shrubs 20-50 cm above ground (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It breeds by direct development, and is not dependent on water. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited.
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. 

Annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thevakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires, but natural fires are unknown in rainforests where the species occurs. The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Additionally, within the central hills various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is patchily distributed across its range, but is abundant where it is found (M. Meegaskumbura and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm. February 2020). However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the Peak Wilderness and the Central Hill Country of southwestern Sri Lanka, and has been recorded at elevations ranging between 810-1,600 m asl (K. Ukuwela pers. comm. February 2020). Known localities include Seethagangula, Sri Palabaddala, Aulton Watta, Norwood, and Moray (M. Wickramasinghe unpub. data 2020). It is not likely to occur more widely than current records suggest (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its distribution is thought to represent five or fewer threat-defined locations due to the influence of tourism and small-scale agriculture on the landscape, and the extent of occurrence (EOO) is 507 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Agra-Bopath Forest Reserve, Rilagela Forest Reserve, and Horton Plains National Park (M. Meegaskumbura and K. Ukuwela pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of loss of habitat, agrochemical pollution, and disturbance by tourism.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 394 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
