population: This species is uncommon and its abundance varies seasonally (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and is was previously known only from the imprecise type locality of "Ceylon [=Sri Lanka]" (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005), rendering it impossible to map. It has since been rediscovered from Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Loolkandura (M. Wickramasinghe unpub. data February 2020), Kolony in Vidulipura village in Norton Bridge (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020), and Mussakele (D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020) where it occurs at elevations ranging between 1,200-1,400 m asl (M.  <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Wickramasinghe"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14851,"3":{"1":0},"4":{"1":3,"3":2},"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":2236962},"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is possible that this species occurs more widely than is currently known (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), but the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its currently mapped distribution is 369 km<sup>2</sup>, and represents three threat defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary and Nature Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed  
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture, tourism, and the potential impacts of climate change. There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,323 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 1-5 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits both closed and open canopy habitats, including grasslands. Most sub-adults and juveniles were found in grassland and disturbed habitats such as home gardens, roadsides, and tea plantations, while mature males and larger females were usually found in closed-canopy habitats. This species is not reliant on canopy cover, and can sometimes be found in tree holes (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Adults have been observed perched on branches 0.5-3.5 m above ground (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It breeds by direct development, and the eggs are deposited in humus.
threats:
The major threats to this species are habitat loss due to the commercial harvesting of timber (clear-cutting) and firewood collection and the desiccation of habitat due to periods of drought, which is likely related to climate change. Annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the Central Hills of Sri Lanka at elevations of 1,300-2,135 m asl. There are records from Agra Bopath, Blackpool, Pattipola, Ambewela, Nuwara Eliya, and Horton Plains (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005, De Silva 2009). This species is not thought to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this distribution is 2,323 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent between 1-5 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Horton Plains National Park, Agra Bopath Forest Reserve, Thangamale Nature Sanctuary, and Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss, acid rain, and climate change.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 7,646 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is largely arboreal, and is associated with the upper story of closed-canopy forest habitats. It has also been observed perched on tall shrubs and occasionally on the forest floor, where it is assumed to have descended to breed. Individuals call from the forest canopy (10-20 m above the ground), even during the daytime (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding takes place by direct development, and is not dependent on water. This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance, as it requires canopy cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A single individual was recorded from within a cardamom plantation, however the plantation was shaded and surrounded by forest.
threats:
This species is threatened by the loss of forest canopy for expansion of cardamom and tea plantations at the expense of cloud forest habitat, clearing of undergrowth, small-scale collection of firewood, and encroaching human settlements. Changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Lowland species (e.g. Psuedophilautus rus and hallidayi encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first inter-monsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously reported as uncommon, however due to increased survey effort it is now known to be common in suitable habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central and southwestern parts of Sri Lanka at elevations of 30-1,270 m asl. There are records from Kosmulla, Dediyagala, Yagirala, Induruwa, Norton Bridge and Haycock (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Records from Handapan Ell Plains, which were previously allocated to Pseudophilautus papillosus, are now assigned to this species (Ellepola et al. 2021). This species is likely to occur between known localities, but is not thought to occur more widely outside of its known and mapped range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,646 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in several protected areas, including Kalugala Forest Reserve, Kanneliya Forest Reserve, Oliyagankela Forest Reserve, Indaruwa Forest Reserve, Sinharaja Forest Reserve, Bambarabodtuwa Forest Reserve, Kottawa Forest Reserve, Yagirala Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness, Runakanda Forest Reserve, and Morningside Forest Reserve (S. Karunarathna, D. Gabadage, M. Botegue, V. Pushpamal, S. Wijayasekara, and P. Samarawickrama pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss due to encroaching agriculture and urbanization, agro-chemical pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,996 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits both closed and open canopy rainforest, where it has been found at night on boulders and branches near streams. It has also been founded in shaded, wet rural gardens, however it is a water associated species and therefore these gardens must contain streams (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is forest and stream-dependent, and is not thought to be tolerant to habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It has not been found away from forest (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). During the day, it hides in rock crevices on the margins of streams. Breeding is by direct development. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited.
threats:
This species is likely threatened by habitat loss due to farming (cultivation of cardamom and tea), small-scale collection of firewood, timber extraction and plantations (pine), and expanding human settlements, as well as pollution by agro-chemicals (resulting in deterioration of water quality). Additional sources of pollution include domestic sources, solid waste, and disturbance by tourists as people bathe in streams (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously thought to be uncommon, but due to increased survey effort it is now known to be abundant within suitable habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central Sri Lanka, occurring in two disjunct subpopulations: one in the Central Hill Country and the other in the Knuckles Range. There are specific records from the Gannoruwa forest and Hanthana Environmental Protected Area (P. Samarawickrama unpub. February 2020), Agra-Bopath, Bogowantalawa, and the Knuckles Range (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005).  It has been recorded at elevations ranging between 1,200-1,600 m asl (Pethiyagoda and Manamendra-Arachchi 2012). This species is not thought to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,996 km2 and its distribution is thought to represent at least two, but no more than five, threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Knuckles Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Hanthana Environmental Protected Area, Gannoruwa Forest Reserve, Punawala Forest Area, Morningside Forest Reserve, Sinharaja World Heritage Site, and Thangamale Protected Area (P. Samarawickrama, D. Kandambi, M. Meegaskumbura and M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss to agriculture, collection of firewood, timber extraction and pine plantations, expanding human settlements, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,101 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This is a leaf-litter species restricted to shaded areas within forests, sometimes close to the forest edge, and is almost never found in areas devoid of canopy cover (Meegaskumbura et al. 2012). This species breeds by direct development, as with congeners.
threats:
Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane (‘cloud’) forests by Perera (1978), and has now also been observed near Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve. Prior to 2013 dieback was never documented in this region, and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: General amphibian surveys conducted in 2000 at the type locality did not record the species, and no other surveys have been done since. Surveys conducted at Rilagala Forest Reserve have encountered 10-15 individuals at a time, which seems to be standard across its range. A 2013 survey conducted at Horton Plains (approximately 6 km from the type locality) successfully recorded the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range:
For 100 years following its description in 1913, this species was known only from the type locality at Pattipola near Nuwara Eliya, Central Province in Sri Lanka, where it had been recorded at 1,829 m asl. 

In 2012, it was rediscovered and redescribed from a specimen collected in 2005 in the Agra-Bopath Forest Reserve, adjoining the Wildlife Heritage Trust’s Agra Field Research Station, at 1,750 m asl, only 8 km away from the type locality (Meegaskumbura et al. 2012). Since 2012, this species was subsequently recorded at Loolcondura (also known as Loolkandura), Hope Estate, Hawagala, and Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (M. Wickramasinghe unpub. data February 2020, S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), as well as from Laxapana Estate in Nallathanniya, Norton Bridge (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020), and Rilagala Forest Reserve (K. Ukuwela unpub. data February 2020). This species' elevational range has been revised to 1,300-1,829 m asl and it is thought to be restricted to this updated distribution (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,101 km2, which is thought to represent five or fewer threat-defined locations due to differing management practices between the protected areas within its range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded in the Agra-Bopath Forest Reserve (Meegaskumbura et al. 2012), Rilagala Forest Reserve, Horton Plains National Park, Loolcondura (also known as Loolkandura) Forest Reserve, and Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of climate change, acid rain, and forest dieback.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,304 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits closed-canopy forests and some anthropogenic habitats, including shaded tea estates adjacent to forests (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Adults have been observed at night on stream banks and perched on branches 1-4 m above ground (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding is by direct development and the species is not dependent on water. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited. This species is not thought to be tolerant to habitat disturbance as it requires canopy cover (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
threats:
Tea cultivation in the areas surrounding the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve are slowly expanding, which is encroaching on the forest and creating pollution from pesticide use. Illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. Expanding human settlements and human-induced fires also pose a threat to this species throughout its range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additionally, within the Central Hills various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species.  Prior to 2013, this dieback was never documented in this region and a large area near Peak Wilderness has now been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane (‘cloud’) forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously known from only two locations in the Central Hill Country of Sri Lanka on either side of the Horton Plains Plateau, near Agarapatana and Haputale. Specific records come from Agra Bopath and the Tangamalai Sanctuary (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It has now also been recorded from the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (Sonaj unpub. data 2020), Mandaram-nuwara (Sameer, Dinesh, Madhava unpub. data 2020) Loolkandura, and Harthana (Wijayathilaka unpub. data 2020). This species is found at elevations between 1,200-1,600 m asl. It is thought to possibly occur more widely, but only within the Central Hill Country (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,304 km<sup>2</sup>, and its distribution is thought to represent five or fewer threat-defined locations in the Central Hills due to different intensities of habitat loss and pollution.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Tangamalai Sanctuary, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Loolkandura Forest Reserve, Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve, and Agra Bopath Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and development, as well as the potential impacts of climate change and acid rain.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Peak Wilderness.
habitat: This is a canopy species, being found at in cloud forest canopy, 1-10 m above the forest floor (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (M. Wickramasinghe and D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area, however at present this species is not being affected.

These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). 

With decrease in the canopy cover, alien invasive species, such as Clusia rosea, and Pteribium revolutum, are widely distributed in lower areas and slowly spreading to higher elevations, which can potentially become a threat in the future if the presence of these species alter the vegetation structure and potential micro-habitats within this species' range (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).
population: This species was known only from the lost holotype until its rediscovery in 2013. There have been no records at the type locality since the species was described in 1853. At its new locality, the species is highly seasonal, being found more often at certain times of year. In general it is thought to be rare, with only 1-2 individuals observed at a single time. Despite a paucity of records, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
range:
This species was previously known only from the type locality of Nuwara Eliya (Newera-Ellia in type locality description), in Sri Lanka (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). No observations have been recorded in this area since 1853 and the species is now believed to be locally extinct at the type locality. 

However, it was rediscovered in Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve in 2013. Records of the species indicate that it has an elevational range of 1,540-1,679 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). This species is not thought to occur more widely (M. Wickramasinghe and D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. February 2020) and the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its extant distribution is 10 km2. The new locality is considered a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place 
This species is known from the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss, pollution, and the impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,853 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in both open and closed-canopy vegetation, including cloud forests and anthropogenic habitats such as home gardens (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Individuals have been observed 1-5 m above ground, perched on leaves and twigs on shrubs, in the forest understory. In closed-canopy habitats, it inhabits the top stratum (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It breeds by direct development and is not dependent on water. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited. This species is fairly tolerant to habitat disturbance, but will not tolerate clear-cutting as it requires some degree of canopy cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
The habitat of this species is gradually declining in extent and quality due to encroachment by small-scale tea cultivation and human settlements, as well as human-induced fires. This species is particularly sensitive to the removal of the humus layer where it lays its eggs. It is probably also threatened by agro-chemicals. 
Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 
Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane (‘cloud’) forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously thought to be uncommon, however after increased survey effort it is now considered to be common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Despite this, a decreasing population trend is inferred from ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to a small part of the Central Hill Country of Sri Lanka where it has been recorded from a few localities, including Agra Bopath, Loolkandura, and Ambewela (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). This species is thought to possibly occur between known localities, and might occur more widely throughout the Central Hill region (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It occurs at elevations ranging between 1,555-1,830 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,853 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is thought to occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations due to differing intensities of agricultural encroachment, pollution, and development.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Horton Plains National Park, Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve, Piduruthalagala Strict Nature Reserve, and the Agra Bopath Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of declining habitat due to agriculture and urbanization, pollution from agro-chemicals and acid rain, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of habitat disturbance, and presumed large stable population.
habitat: This species occurs in both the wet and dry zones of Sri Lanka. It is generally an arboreal species of secondary forest habitats (including degraded forest), but can also occur in banana groves, home gardens, homes and other buildings. It is not present in primary forest. Larvae may be found in semi-permanent pools, stock tanks, and in stagnant water, including in human-altered habitats. This species is adaptable and is therefore thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species include pollution from agro-chemicals, such as pesticides, and fires within its range. Climate change could potentially pose a threat to this species within the southwestern lowlands portion of its range. However, due to this species wide distribution and elevational range, it is not as susceptible to the impacts of climate change as other species and therefore it is considered a minor threat overall. 

Forest dieback could also be an additional threat to this species, however there is currently no direct evidence (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected. It is primarily thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is common and its population is stable (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species was previously known to be widely distributed throughout southwestern Sri Lanka, and is now known to occur across most of the country, including between known localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It has been recorded at elevations between sea level and 1,600 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from many protected areas including the Udawattakele Sanctuary in Kandy, and Victoria-Randenigala-Rantambe Sanctuary, Kanneliya Forest Reserve and Singharaja World Heritage Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,991 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is arboreal and terrestrial; adults are found in the canopy, on tree trunks, and in open areas within montane tropical moist forest, and also in grasses at the edge of ponds. Larvae are found in both permanent and seasonal ponds in grasslands. This species does not seem tolerant of disturbance, as it is not present in modified habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
The Knuckles Mountain Forest Reserve (KMFR) faces severe and imminent threats including extensive agricultural practices, in particular illegal cardamom plantations (Weerawardhena and Russell 2012) and the resulting pollution from pesticide use. Much of the primary forest of the KMFR has been cleared to make way for the cultivation of cash-crops (tea and cardamom), which includes the gathering of wood to use in cardamom processing and drying barns, and to supply timber and fuelwood for villages (Weerawardhena and Russell 2012). Furthermore, unregulated research work, and the construction of resorts and other buildings including houses, uncontrolled tourism access, and human-set forest fires constitute further threats to the KMFR (Weerawardhena and Russell 2012, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). In the Central Hills, various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, and M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). This species is also threatened by parasitic infection in the subcutaneous tissue (de Silva 2009).

Climate change also poses a threat, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Despite this, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is found in the Central Hills and Knuckles Forest Reserve of Sri Lanka at elevations of 1,000-2,300 m asl (De Silva 2009, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Records previously mapped from Morningside were mistakenly identified and are now known to represent T. fastigo (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is likely restricted to this revised range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,991 km2, and is thought to occur in at least two but fewer than five threat-defined locations due to differing intensities of agricultural encroachment, tourism, and development.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the Horton Plains National Park, Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve, Knuckles Forest Reserve, and the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Efforts from the Upula Forest Department since 2000 have worked to halt the expansion of cardamom plantations within the reserve. As a result, the recovery of canopy cover has been documented (Upula Forest Department pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agriculture-induced habitat loss, agro-chemical pollution, infrastructure development and tourism, small-scale wood extraction, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This subterranean species inhabits evergreen forests, rubber plantations, tea plantations, paddy fields, rural gardens and farms, wetlands (boggy areas), and cattle pastureland. The adults are often found in humus. It is assumed to be oviparous with terrestrial eggs and aquatic larvae.

This species has been recorded in agricultural habitats that retain high enough levels of vegetation and moisture. However, it is not thought to be tolerant of more extreme changes that result in much lower soil moisture levels, consistently alter soil chemistry, and have have the potential to result in fragmentation (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Furthermore, it appears to be less adaptable than Ichthyophis glutinosus.
threats:
The species is known from both intact habitats and agricultural landscapes. Elevated levels of human activity may actually be causing a high enough level of disturbance such that it constitutes a cause for concern. Therefore, localized threats are considered to be extreme habitat loss due to agroindustry and clear cutting, as well as heavy use of pesticides and other agrochemicals due to chemical leaching into the soil. In addition, since 2005, construction of large-scale dams, large-scale hydropower stations (Kalugaga and Moragahakanda, established in 2019), several small-scale hydropower stations, as well as water extraction for agricultural purposes in some localities, all pose a threat to this species as these activities cause desiccation of larval habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additional threats include roads, road construction, and the accompanying concrete barriers and drains within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Sand mining and subsequent erosion is a threat throughout its range (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020), as is land filling for domestic waste. 

Climate change also poses a threat to the species due to changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of rainfall, which results in the soil drying (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon and was last recorded from within the Pattipola Reserve in 1986, despite five general amphibian surveys to the area, and many general amphibian surveys conducted throughout the rest of its known range which failed to record the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The most recent record is from Haldummulla in 2004 (S. Karunarathna unpub. data 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the mountains of south central Sri Lanka. It has been recorded at elevations between 460-1,890 m asl and is likely restricted to its currently known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2 </sup>and, given the possibility of local extinctions and the ongoing threat of clear-cutting within its small range, this species is likely restricted to fewer than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Pattipola Forest Reserve and Namunakula Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and pollution throughout its range. Additionally, it is necessary to investigate about this species complex in order to elucidate the taxonomic identity of its members.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,131 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits closed-canopy montane forests and cardamom plantations within the forest. Males call from their perches on leaves 1-3 m above the ground (Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi 2005). Breeding is by direct development; the female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited. It is dependent on relatively undisturbed closed-canopy cloud forest, and will therefore not tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
The major threat is clearing of the species' forest habitat, due to subsistence agriculture and logging. 

Climate change also poses a threat, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: The number of individuals encountered varies and only a few individuals are ever encountered at one time, therefore the species is considered to be uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat.
range: This Sri Lankan endemic is restricted to the highest elevations of the Central Hills and is currently known only from Horton Plains National Park at 2,135 m asl, Namunukula Peak at 1,850-1,980 m asl, Piduruthalagala forest at 2,300 m asl, and Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It is separated from its sister species, P. auratus, by a 1,450 m deep valley (Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi 2005) and it is not thought to occur more widely. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its distribution is 2,131 km2, which is thought to represent four threat-defined locations - one for each of the protected areas in which it occurs, due to their differing management practices.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The range of this species includes Horton Plains National Park, Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve, and Peak Wilderness Wildlife Sanctuary (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of conversion of its forest habitat to cardamom plantations and subsistence agriculture, as well as the threat of drought and forest dieback.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 635 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is restricted to the highest elevations of the Knuckles Range, and is found in closed-canopy habitats in the leaf-litter, shrubs and trees in the sub-canopy. Males are seen calling from branches 0.3-3 m above the ground (Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi 2005). Breeding is presumed to take place by direct development. This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance, as it requires canopy cover (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
threats:

Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction.
